brewers_tips: Make sure your hops are well broken up and mixed in when added to the kettle for aroma additions. The wort is not boiling so is not agitating the hops to allow mixing. If the hops aren't steeped properly in the wort you won't get the maximum flavour impact.

metodo.torsione: Based on AB:04, but with added vanilla and 3.5 times the chilli.

brewers_tips: Be really careful when mashing, as this amount of malts can get tough to sparge! Add honey into the boil, and naga chili and vanilla in maturation (soak them in some neutral spirit to sanitise).

abbinamento_cibo: Grilled spicy corn with feta crumbles
brewers_tips: HBC 369 is now known as Mosaic!
Achieve the red colour by using the ratio of Caramalt, Crystal and Dark Crystal malts. The trick is to get the colour, without too much dried fruit character.

Noble hops (and their offspring) have a fundamentally different profile to many other hops, down to their different oil fractions. Chill your hops to retain all of the spicy, delicate volatile hop oils!
Get hops in every stage of the brewing process - mash, run off boil and flame off. There's not too much malt body, so the more hops the better.

metodo.torsione: Toasted coconut flakes: 75g, Cacao Nibs: 25g

brewers_tips: Add the coconut and cacao nibs after primary fermentation and let infuse for at least 6 months at a low temperature.

abbinamento_cibo: Grilled salmon with a herb and citrus infused butter
Basil, lemon and pine nut angel hair pasta with grilled chicken
brewers_tips: Sorachi Ace is hop best handled with care. Too much and your beer may taste like dill pickle and lemons.
Use bourbon-soaked oak chips in secondary to achieve barrel character.

metodo.torsione: Raspberries in the boil, rhubarb at maturation. Soured naturally using the kettle souring technique, Raspberries at middle

malto.nome: Propino Pale Malt for kettle souring

brewers_tips: Fruits added at the end of the boil for 10 mins and additional added in maturation. Boil for no more than 15 mins.
Age this beer in the cellar for a few months to allow the warm alcohol flavours to reduce.

metodo.torsione: Oak chips: 15g, Fresh strawberries: 3kg

brewers_tips: Rack into a secondary fermenter and add your strawberries. Use a blow-off rather than an airlock as the fermentation can get pretty wild as the yeast starts using the sugar from the strawberries.
Play around with the fermentation temperature to get the best flavour profile from the individual yeasts.

abbinamento_cibo: Tuna sushi roll with spicy mayonnaise sauce
brewers_tips: New Zealand hops are in short supply - club together with other brewers to try and get hold of some, or ask your local brewery if you can buy small amounts from them.

metodo.torsione: Fruit in the boil, berries in the fermenter. Limonnik Berries: 2.5, Twist.

brewers_tips: If you can't get hold of Limonnik berries, rose hips make an accessible alternative!

metodo.torsione: Coffee: 25g at end, Coffee: 25g at end, Dark Muscavado Sugar: 250g at end

brewers_tips: Use freshly ground coffee for the best aromatic hit.

abbinamento_cibo: Spicy wings with blue cheese dip
Pan seared scallops with a chilli sauce
brewers_tips: There are so much hops in this beer it may break your gear! Watch out for the end of casting (or knockout for our American brethern), you don’t want to pull too much trub into the fermenter.

abbinamento_cibo: Fish corn tacos with pomegranate salsa
brewers_tips: Using a starter to get your yeast as vibrant and healthy as possible will make all the difference here.
Hold the mash for longer at 63-64°C to get more fermentability from the wort.

abbinamento_cibo: Barbecue pulled pork on sourdough bread
Roast turkey with a honey and herb marinade and roasted vegetables
Banana walnut loaf with chocolate chips
brewers_tips: Keep the fermentation temperature as close to 19°C as possible. This will ensure the yeast creates a more neutral flavour profile, allowing the hops to really shine through.

The biggest challenge with this beer is getting it to ferment out entirely. Hold mash temp at 65°C for 90 mins to ensure maximum fermentability. Use super high gravity yeast or champagne yeast to achieve the last few gravity points.

metodo.torsione: Adding popped popcorn into the mash, then barrel ageing in fresh bourbon barrels

brewers_tips: By soaking some oak chips in bourbon, then steeping in the beer you not only get an authentic Bourbon taste - the beer will also gain ABV! Add salt to taste, too much will totally ruin the balance of the beer.
Take a read through each year’s hop harvest that is available. Some years are better than others.

metodo.torsione: Oak chips: 25g at end

brewers_tips: Boil for even longer to get more caramelised flavours in the beer.

metodo.torsione: Aged in rum casks for 12 months

brewers_tips: Ageing in barrels brings the ABV up. Recreate rum cask ageing by soaking oak chips in rum then adding to the maturing beer.
For a fresh and fiery hit, put some ginger into the cold conditioning phase as well.

metodo.torsione: Try ageing on oak chips, infusing with rum raisins, or vanilla pods

abbinamento_cibo: Rum poached pears with dark chocolate sauce
brewers_tips: The beauty of this beer is in how brilliantly it lends itself to infusing or ageing. Experiment with different additions when the beer is ageing, taste it regularly to gauge its progress, and make sure you package it at its peak.
The addition of Weyermann Beech Smoked malt creates a beer with a delicate smoke character.

abbinamento_cibo: Rocket and mozzarella salad with a cracked pepper dressing
Fried halibut with sweet potato fritters
brewers_tips: 20% specialty malts in this grist can create problems in the run off. Be careful not to pull the bed down onto the plates.

abbinamento_cibo: Fried American bacon with chilli flakes added to the top
brewers_tips: Use the freshest hops for the most impact. It seems obvious but in a single hop beer, you want the hops to be at their best.

metodo.torsione: Coffee Beans: 12.5g at end, Lactose: 125g

abbinamento_cibo: Beef chilli made with cocoa powder
brewers_tips: There is a huge amount of roasted malts in this grist. Be careful not to pulverise the malt into powder during the milling process.
Soak some oak chips in Caol Ila whisky to get barrel character. Freeze raspberries before adding them to secondary.

metodo.torsione: Coffee added after boil. Aged on French oak chips., Dark muscovado sugar: 312.5g for 20mins

abbinamento_cibo: Chicken fried steak with cheesy mash
brewers_tips: Grind the coffee as if making an espresso to really get the most out of it.
We've mentioned the importance of fresh hops previously but this one really demands that your hops are the absolute freshest.

metodo.torsione: Heather Honey: 125g

abbinamento_cibo: Mature cheddar with red onion chutney
brewers_tips: There's a lot of specialty malt in the mash. Make sure you take the run off nice and steady – increase the flow too much and pull in the bed at your peril.

metodo.torsione: Cumin: 0.5g at end, Caraway: 1g at end, Peppercorns (Pink): 5g at end, Grains of Paradise: 5g at end

abbinamento_cibo: Spicy Daal with garlic naan bread
brewers_tips: Start the fermentation off at 20 ̊C and allow it to rise as high as 25 ̊C. This will increase the fruity character of the yeast.

metodo.torsione: Cacao: 25g at FV, Coffee Beans: 37.5g at FV, Oak Chips: 5g at FV, Vanilla Pods: 10 split pods, Liquorice: 5g at FV

abbinamento_cibo: Caramelised scallops with burnt apple puree
brewers_tips: Add all twist ingredients to Fermentation Vessel once fermentation is complete. Don’t be afraid to add a little at a time and taste as you go. During mashing in first start with pale malt. Afterwards mix all malts evenly. Go with flaked oats during second half of mashing in process.

metodo.torsione: Seabuckthorn: 25g at end, Sea Salt: 20g at middle, Rum: 25ml at end

abbinamento_cibo: Salt baked cod with lemon and dill butter
brewers_tips: Keep the fermentation temperature as steady as possible to allow the lager yeast to do its thing.
Sit this beer aside for a month to allow it to mellow.

abbinamento_cibo: Grilled vegetable and chicken teriyaki skewers

metodo.torsione: Cranberry: 25g at end, Jasmine: 25g at end, Muscovado sugar: 300g at start, Oak chips soaked in lowland whisky: 15g at dry hop

brewers_tips: Leave on wood for as long as you dare. If possible forget about it for four years.

abbinamento_cibo: Barbecue corn and steak fajita seasoned wrap
brewers_tips: To dry the beer out, mash at a slightly lower temp (62° - 63°C), this will increase the ratio of fermentable sugars in the beer.

abbinamento_cibo: Shredded chicken and mango salsa taquitos
brewers_tips: After the beer has fermented, leave it to rest for 2 – 3 days at the lowest temperature possible (ideally 0 – 2'C). This will allow the flavours to marry together, and will transform it into a balanced and amazing beer.

metodo.torsione: Coffee Beans: 250g FV. Raisins: 90g at end. Dark Sugar:140g at end.

abbinamento_cibo: Gorgonzola and rye nut bread with smoked honey ham

Fresh pico de gallo with corn tortilla
brewers_tips: Create balance through experimentation with the hop amounts and malt backbone.

metodo.torsione: Kettle Soured

brewers_tips: Lemon poppyseed donuts.

metodo.torsione: Fermented with Belgian yeast for signature character

metodo.torsione: Roasted Hazelnuts: 25g in Tank (FV), Almonds: 12.5g in Tank (FV), Oak Chips: 25g in Tank (FV)

Add the rye and wheat malt evenly through the mash.

metodo.torsione: Age in rum barrels, Tayberries: 500g, Purple Raspberries: 500g

abbinamento_cibo: Candied almond and blue cheese rocket salad

metodo.torsione: Add chillies, cacoa and naga chillies to the cold conditioning

brewers_tips: Make sure you can get the coffee, cocoa and chillies out of the beer when the flavours are right.

abbinamento_cibo: Panna cotta with a grapefruit tuile

metodo.torsione: Herb and honey addition

brewers_tips: Get really good quality heather honey, the more aromatic the better. Honey is 100% fermentable, but it does have a huge influence on the ester profile of the beer – in this case high floral esters.

abbinamento_cibo: Spicy beef and Mexican black bean burger
brewers_tips: Columbus and Ahtanum hop additions create a perfect blend of resin and lemon character.

abbinamento_cibo: Shredded chicken tacos with pico de gallo

metodo.torsione: Oak Chips: 38.5g at FV, Vanilla Pods at FV

brewers_tips: Steep the oak chips and vanilla in separate bags in the cold conditioning phase. Taste every 2 - 3 days and as soon as profile is desirable they can be removed easily.
It may be tempting to throw extra (extra) hops at Dead Pony Club, but try adding a little at a time to consecutive brews rather than cramming in loads extra on your first time.

metodo.torsione: Lactose: 125g, Scottish Heather Honey: 125g, Raspberries: 187.5g

Rich beef stew with winter vegetables and a dash of honey

metodo.torsione: Kettle Soured, 5 Mangoes pureed at FV

brewers_tips: Try to use the juiciest, ripest mangoes possible.

abbinamento_cibo: Pan roasted poussin with spring veg

metodo.torsione: Ice-distilled after fermentation to get to 18.3%

ingredienti.lievito: Wyeast 1056 - American Ale™ & Wyeast 1272 - American Ale II™

brewers_tips: Ferment first with the American ale strain and after a week add the American Ale II to really push up the ABV. Use a starter to get the yeast raring and ready to go before the second addition.

metodo.torsione: Pumkin puree: 375g, Grains of Paradise: 2.5g at end, Star Anise: 1.5g at end, Cinnamon: 2.5g at end, Nutmeg: 2.5g at end, Allspice: 2.5g at end, Ginger: 2.5g at end, Clove: 2.5g at end

metodo.torsione: Add grapefruit and orange peel into the boil and FV for extra citrus twist

abbinamento_cibo: Coriander and lime green thai curry
brewers_tips: Shave of the surface of the citrus peel to unlock the highly aromatic compounds into the beer. Avoid putting any white pith into the brew as it will create an intense and unpleasant bitterness.

abbinamento_cibo: Pan seared venison with fruit salad side
Caramelised apple pie with vanilla ice cream

20% of the original volume of wort was brewed again, kettle soured and added during fermentation to give a tart finish to the beer.

Blackberry pie with vanilla ice cream

Cheesecake with a passion fruit swirl sauce

abbinamento_cibo: Spicy black bean and chicken tortilla soup

abbinamento_cibo: Espresso crusted venison with a dark cherry jus

metodo.torsione: Use Perigold Truffles after fermentation

brewers_tips: A little truffle goes a long way. Add 5g, leave for a 2 days and add more if needed.

Shortbread and raspberry jam thumbprint cookie

Cardamom cake with powder sugar and cloudberry jam

abbinamento_cibo: Strawberry and basil salad with feta
brewers_tips: Dry hop using a muslin bag in order to give you the best chance at getting the signature Kölsch clarity.

abbinamento_cibo: Seared steak with a peppercorn sauce
brewers_tips: Add the chocolate malt after the mash is complete, at the start of sparging. This will extract flavour and colour, but will prevent the extraction of harsh tannins into the wort.
Get the freshest Simcoe for the best profile.
Don’t overcook the mash - 75 minutes only at 65°C to get the right amount of fermentable sugars. Leave it too long and the beer ends up really watery and unpleasant.

metodo.torsione: Passionfruit: 438g at End

abbinamento_cibo: Grilled lamb chops with a fruit reduction
Ginger and chilli beef stir fry
brewers_tips: Try adding some of the passionfruit in the cold conditioning phase.
Extend the mash time as much as possible to create maximum fermentable sugars. Boil for longer in the kettle to help evaporate off the water, and make the sugar concentration stronger.

abbinamento_cibo: Habanero spicy chicken wings with ranch sauce
brewers_tips: Allow the mash to sit at lower temperatures for an extended period to convert the maximum amount of starch to fermetable sugars. This will give the beer a higher ABV and dry it out.

metodo.torsione: Cranberry: 25g at end, Jasmine: 25g at end, Muscovado sugar: 500g at start, Oak chips soaked in lowland whisky: 15g at dry hop

abbinamento_cibo: Rib eye steak with a compound butter
brewers_tips: Leave on wood for as long as you dare. If possible forget about it for four years.

abbinamento_cibo: Sticky spicy barbecue ribs with a strong blue cheese dipping sauce
Creamy warm baked goats cheese salad
brewers_tips: Watch out for collecting too much wort. Collecting too much liquid from run off (under 1008) may impart massive and undesired 'grainy' flavours into the beer

The most important thing about making a lager? Fermentation temperature! Do everything you can to control the ambient temperature to 9 - 12°C. In the old days, they used to brew lager over winter, so the colder temperature gave a much preferable fermentation profile. Ferment too hot and you beer will taste like yeasty bread.

abbinamento_cibo: Cheddar cheese toastie on dark rye
Lamb samosas with chilli dipping sauce
brewers_tips: These beers need to hit FG to really pop. If you're fermentation is struggling, whip up a starter and re-pitch to get some viable yeast in there to finish the job
Age the beer in bottle for a few months at cellar temperature to allow the hot alcohol characteristic to diminish.
Add .75g (0.026oz) of Brewers Clarex to your fermentation vessel during casting.

abbinamento_cibo: Grilled king prawns with a chilli lime sauce
brewers_tips: The goal here is to make a black beer that tastes like an IPA. Don't overload the black or roasted malts to try and achieve the correct colour. Too much roasted malts will suppress far too much of that beautiful citrus and tropical flavour from the Simcoe. It may be hard to get hold of Carafa, but it will allow you to get a great colour, without all of the characteristic roasty astringent flavours.

abbinamento_cibo: Pork burrito with a habanero and mango chilli salsa
brewers_tips: Be aware that this is probably the hoppiest beer you will ever make. Make sure you use fresh hops, for a massive fresh grapefruit hit. Have everything else in your store cupboard, and buy your hops last, as close to brew day as possible!

metodo.torsione: This beer is an odd one in our collection as it is a blend of two recipes that feature elsewhere. These recipes are #123 Everyday Anarchy and #124 Black Jacques. Both Imperial Saisons spent a little under a year in white and red wine barrels respectively. However, while the pair were being tasted to determine their readiness to be released, a fun game of blending turned into a light bulb moment. The beers were blended and laid down once more in our barrel cellar, this time being infused with the heady note of rum. We were so excited about this mystical blend that we ended up using up all the beer that had been lovingly aged. It would have been a travesty for these beers to go unrecognised as the unique individuals they were, so we brewed them again in 2013 to be released as had always been intended. Age the individual beers separately before blending and ageing further on oak chips soaked in rum.

brewers_tips: It can be difficult to get the perfect balance between both beers. Set up several small blends of varying percentages to determine which you prefer.

abbinamento_cibo: Thyme, rosemary and black pepper rubbed roast beef served with fried green beans
brewers_tips: We also produced two separate barrel- aged versions of this beer; Bashah 2009 Highland Park and Black Raspberry Reserve, and Bashah 2009 Imperial and Tayberry Reserve were two barrel aged versions of the beer. Try ageing this beer on oak or with fruit to make your own reserve.
Challenger hops come from English hops farms - try getting hold of some fresh, undried hops and make a "wet hop" beer.

ingredienti.lievito: Wyeast 1056 - American Ale™ & Wyeast 1272 - American Ale II™

abbinamento_cibo: Jalapeño poppers with blue cheese dip
Carrot cake with cream cheese frosting
brewers_tips: Enigma has a very high alpha acid so be careful not to over do the bittering hops.

abbinamento_cibo: Chicken fajita spiced monteray jack quesadillas
Chilli lime and coriander marinated king prawn cocktail
brewers_tips: Chinook is a hop that can really shine on its own so don't be shy and really throw it at this IPA

metodo.torsione: Yuzu juice: 250g at FV

abbinamento_cibo: Fresh seared tuna and rocket salad
brewers_tips: Squeeze the fresh yuzu juice directly into the beer after primary fermentation is complete. Putting it in the hot wort may seem like better practice, but the juice will cook and some of the fresh citrus character will be lost.

metodo.torsione: Age in whisky casks with rum soaked raisins

brewers_tips: Soak oak chips in rum, then steep in the beer for the rum cash finish.

abbinamento_cibo: Honey glazed ham with spicy roasted carrots
brewers_tips: In beers like this with a hefty malt bill, it pays to check a spoonful of the mash with some iodine solution. This will indicate if the mash has converted all of the starch into fermentable sugars. If the colour is very dark, just extend the mash rest by 10 mins and check again.

metodo.torsione: Add 1 naga chilli in the FV

brewers_tips: Steep the coffee in the hot wort for short periods to get the best extraction of aromatic oils, without gaining too much bitterness.
Get the freshest Simcoe for the best profile.

abbinamento_cibo: Spicy pork sausages with red potato mash
Turnip beef stew with crusty fresh baked bread
brewers_tips: Dry Hopping: Columbus 37.5g, Centennial 37.5g, Galena 37.5g, Horizon 37.5g

abbinamento_cibo: Fried calamari with a mild sauce
brewers_tips: Wheat and flaked oats can help to add to the body of the beer. This makes up for the lack of alcoholic bite.

abbinamento_cibo: Gorgonzola and rye nut bread with smoked honey ham
brewers_tips: You can always add more hops, but it is difficult to take them away. Carry out multiple additions of the hops during dry hopping to achieve the best profile.

abbinamento_cibo: Prawn toast with sweet chilli sauce
brewers_tips: In any low ABV fermentation after primary fermentation has finished if the beer smells or tastes like wort, allow it to condition on the yeast for an extra 24 - 48 hours. This can round the profile off well.
Keep the temperature of the fermentation as close to 12C as possible (or below). This allows the yeast to create a crisper and cleaner beer.
Ensure you aerate the wort to get a nice clean fermentation and really get the best out of the UK hops.

metodo.torsione: Cranberry: 25g at end, Jasmine: 25g at end, Muscovado sugar: 300g at start, Oak chips: 15g at FV

metodo.torsione: Jasmine addition in cold conditioning

brewers_tips: When dry hopping with the jasmine, use a muslin or cloth like a tea bag, and make sure it has a heavy object in it (ensure its clean). This will help to keep the jasmine submerged in the beer for better flavour extraction.
Munich malt adds a biscuit sweetness, while the rye adds a spicy bready character.

metodo.torsione: Try ageing on oak chips, infusing with rum raisins, or vanilla pods

Beer affogato - 1/3 glass of Paradox with a scoop of vanilla ice cream

Cured ham and strong mulled cheddar board

Be careful with the rye malt in the run off. It can lead to stuck mashes and extended collection periods.

metodo.torsione: Before main fermentation steep a bag of malt in the wort for 48 hours. Re boil the wort before pitching in the yeast for the main fermentation.

Cheesecake with raspberry (or peach/passion fruit) sauce
brewers_tips: Making sour beers is an art, and is mostly related to trial and error with your process. Experiment with different temperatures for steeping the grain. 40 - 50°C willallow the lacto to grow and produce a clean profile.

brewers_tips: When you have a good lactobacillus culture grown take half of an fv of it and add some fresh wort. This will keep the culture alive as long as you keep it warm, oxygen free and keep releasing the pressure. You can then use this liquid culture on the next brew and reuse it over and over and over and over and over...like sourdough starter!

Use only very dry coffee beans like Sumatran ones. This way your head retention will not be affected by the oils from the beans.

Use whole leaf hops for the dry hopping. They’re much easier to get out.

Let the wort sit for 30 minutes after flameout before cooling to get the most out of that last hop addition.

Add the cloudberries to your beer when racking the beer after primary fermentation. Grind them into a paste to allow maximum flavour extraction.

Bring a few bottles to your local BrewDog bar when it's done and ask the staff if you got it right, they're the only ones who can tell you for sure! They'll also probably know of other homebrewers and beer enthusiasts nearby that you can link in with to share your experiences and get awesome first hand advice from.

metodo.torsione: Kettle Soured

Lightly toast the coconut chips to allow better interaction with the hot wort.

We don't recommend roulette as a way to design beer. Spin the bottle is a much more sensible option. Make this beer with the freshest ingredients you can. Try to arrange brewday as close to delivery day as possible and throw 10 brewbucks on black 17 for us.

metodo.torsione: Toasted Coconut Chips – 40g FV & Vanilla Extract – FV

brewers_tips: Don't be shy with the roasted coconut, it's a delicate flavour compared to the rest of the beer, so go nuts! If it grows wild near you, go grab some Gorse and chuck it in too for a local natural boost to the coconut flavours.

brewers_tips: If you can't find an awesome Scottish band to collaborate with just pump up the volume on your stereo and have fun moshing whilst you're mashing in. Use ripe but fresh fruit and be prepared to lose extra volume to it. It'll be worth it.

abbinamento_cibo: Pork Burrito with a Habanero and Mango Chili Salsa
brewers_tips: This level of alcohol can be achieved using a domestic freezer. Use a container with a tap close to the bottom so you can run the un-frozen, concentrated beer from under the ice on top. You may have to do this three or four times. The colder you freeze it the boozier it gets. Be careful to not dilute it too much when draining off the concentrated liquid after freezing so you don’t dilute it too much.
Be prepared for a long sparge as the rye content is really high.

metodo.torsione: Crushed Coridaner Seeds – FV

brewers_tips: If you dry hop with extra Sorachi Ace you'll end up with an awesome extra hit of lemony zing but be warned, it'll go through a lot of interesting variations on the way, including coconut and even bubblegum! Give it time though and it'll land back at that lovely lemon zest that will compliment the coriander seeds perfectly.
To really nail this style you need to get the water right. Do a bit of research on water profiles and ask a local brewery if they can help you out with some water treatments.

Pre-mix your malts to keep the conversion of starches to sugars even across the mash and give you a more uniform grain bed for lautering and sparging. This is a lot less labour intensive than manually stirring your speciality malts into your mash tun.
Kellerbier translates to cellar beer, if you don’t have a cellar just make sure to keep the fermentation temperature as close as possible to what you'd expect in a bavarian basement.
Brew twice as much Belgian Tripel as you were planning on ageing - it's awesome on its own too!
Add the dry hops in separate muslin bags to increase surface area contact and reduce the amount of hop matter in the beer after dry hopping without reducing the characteristic hazy look of the beer.

Surface area contact is key in dry additions. Make sure your coffee and cacao nibs are weighed down with something and spread them out between multiple muslin bags if you can. This is not an exact science so taste as you go and swap out for fresh coffee and/or cacao if you haven't gotten the flavour you want after five days or so. You will not have this problem with the vanilla.

metodo.torsione: Age this beer in Rye Whisky Casks.

brewers_tips: The beauty of this beer is in how brilliantly it lends itself to infusing or ageing. Experiment with different additions when the beer is ageing, taste it regularly to gauge its progress, and make sure you package it at its peak.

If you are feeling adventurous, and haven’t guzzled your whole batch upon first tasting it, try mulling this like you would a wine or cider. Cinnamon and clove will really lend themselves to the flavour of Tropic Thunder and mulled beer is definitely cooler than the usual offerings at a winter gathering.

abbinamento_cibo: Baked Peaches with Citrus Fruit Reduction
brewers_tips: Skip the arrageenan (Irish Moss), all haze is good haze in this beer.

* Not a suitable replacement for an actual breakfast. Nitroing at home is, well, not impossible but unlikely. Luckily this beer tastes great when lightly carbonated too! Be prepared for a slow runoff and don’t skimp on the cacao!

DON’T add flour. This “tip” has been floating around for the style and it’s bad advice. Any and all murk should accompany something that enhances the beer. This little juice-box is dry hopped at a rate of 10g per litre. Wonder what would happen if you doubled that...

abbinamento_cibo: Goat's Cheese Salad With Walnuts, Radish And Blood Orange
brewers_tips: After boiling your wort, chill the wort down quickly to avoid the compound DMS forming. DMS gives beer a tinned sweetcorn like aroma.
Vermont Yeast, whilst desirable for this style of beer, is not absolutely necessary. The murk of a NEIPA can be achieved by malt selection and your process.
Adding the fruit at the end of the boil effectively pasteurises it. If you plan to add fruit after primary fermentation, buy aseptic puree or have a plan to pasteurise it before adding it.
Dextrin Malt adds sugars to your wort that the yeast are unable to ferment. If you want a sweetness remaining in your beer, add a little of this but not too much!!!

luppolo.nome: American Oak Chips Medium Toast Soaked In Speyside Whisky

brewers_tips: Soak American oak (medium toasted) chips in your favourite Speyside tipple overnight and add them after primary fermentation
This beer is supposed to be very cloudy. Don’t be shy to get a good bit of the hot break into the fermenter.
A German style wheat beer that is mostly defined by its yeast character. Yeast strain has a massive influence on the final perception of the beer.
An oxymoron of a beer. The cocoa nibs are vital in providing that stout like flavour without the associated colour.

abbinamento_cibo: Feta And Tomato Salad With Balsamic Dressing
brewers_tips: Add heather honey to your boil to make this beer even better!!!
Spelt malt can slow your run off, similar to Rye. Take your time or add some extra malt to compensate for lower efficiency.

abbinamento_cibo: Hot Wings And Blue Cheese Dip
Sticky Toffee Pudding And Salted Caramel Ice Cream
brewers_tips: The hopping rate should leave a light residual haze in your beer after maturation. Don’t worry, this comes from the hop compounds, haze is taste.
If you want the colour but less of the flavour of the dark malts, try substituting the Carafa Special III for a dehusked version of Carafa.
Play around with the citrus flavour by using differing amounts of lemon peel, orange peel, grapefruit peel, lime peel or kaffir lime leaves.
If you want more phenolic (Banana & Spice) flavours, ferment at a higher temperature. If you want more fruit esters, keep the fermentation lower and under control.
This yeast strain produces a marked sulphurous note in the beer. If that’s not your thing, don’t Burtonise your mash and see the difference!

brewers_tips: Never put honey into your beer without pasteurising it. It is full of wild yeasts that are waiting to spoil your hard work.

abbinamento_cibo: Barbeque and Mustard Beef on Rye Bread
brewers_tips: Rye can cause run off problems. Try to reach a temperature of 78 degrees Celsius if possible, and sparge at the same temperature.

metodo.torsione: 10kg of glacier water added to the mash.

brewers_tips: So your homebrew shop of choice may not stock all the ingredients here! You can buy cloudberry jam and add that instead. The pectin in the jam is not ideal and will form a haze but that can be forgiven in a saison.

luppolo.nome: American Oak Chips Heavy Toast Soaked in Bourbon

abbinamento_cibo: Cherry Chocolate Cake With Chocolate Whipped Mousse
brewers_tips: Be careful with brown malt. If you put too much in, it can very easily turn a fantastic tasting beer into a beer that tastes like someone has poured a pint into an ash tray, swirled it around and put it back into your pint.

abbinamento_cibo: Baked Tilapia With Lemon and Cream Sauce
brewers_tips: Be careful with your salt additions. A very light saltiness aids the refreshing character. It should not overpower or drive you to seek another different beer to refresh your palate.

abbinamento_cibo: Espresso brownies with burnt sugar ice cream
brewers_tips: Do not substitute the muscovado sugar with white sugar. It lacks the molasses (black treacle) component that comes from only being partially refined.
Morello Cherries are the go to cherry variety for this beer (and Krieks), the sour compliments the residual sweetness of the malt. Works well if you reduce your IBU to the 20 to 30 range too.

abbinamento_cibo: Steamed cod with ginger and spring onions
brewers_tips: Instead of adding the blueberry juice in the kettle. Add fresh blueberries to your secondary fermenter, pitch The Yeast Bay's Melange Sour Blend and wait for 1 year.
Strawberry is a very delicate flavour, so don’t shy away with putting a lot more in when you dry hop.
Save yourself a lot of hassle and buy the blackcurrant as a concentrate or cordial. Ribena time!
Add the lingonberry juice either to the end of the boil or to the fermenter, depending on whether the juice has been pasteurised.
The Seville Orange is a bitter orange, so adjust your bittering hop addition down to account for the fact that there will be a contribution from them.

Save yourself a lot of hassle and buy the Elderflower as a concentrate or cordial. Collecting elderberries ranks low on the FPES (fruit picking enjoyment scale), can't imagine the flower picking is much better.
Keep an eye on your pH as you are adding your lemon juice. Yeast can tolerate low pH conditions but the length of fermentation may take longer than normal.
Using the mandarin in the mash means you can also throw in the peel to extract the essential oils from it. The pith can be quite bitter if it makes it into the boil.

luppolo.nome: American Oak Chips Medium Toast soaked in Speyside Whisky
American Oak Chips Heavy Toast soaked in Speyside Whisky

brewers_tips: Don’t be too quick to rack the beer off the yeast once your final gravity is reached. The stressed yeast will be absorbing a number of undesirable fermentation by-products such as acetaldehyde and diacetyl. Give them a minimum of 10 days at fermentation temperature to do this before cooling it down.
Pectin powder can easily be sourced and is an easy alternative for a homebrewer to produce murky beer if you don’t have access to a low flocculating yeast.
